About Forty Rooters Will See
First Game Away
Playing its first out-of-town game
of this season, the Hopkins lacrosse
twelve will meet Swarthmore tomorrow at the latter team's home
field.
It will be interesting to compare
the showing made by Swarthmore
against Hopkins with the result of
the Garnets' contest with the West
Point twelve. Army, which has
been undefeated, upset _ Swarthmore's hopes when it trounced the
Garnet team 18 to 6. Hopkins followers are looking to this game to
prove in some measure whether the
Black and Blue team was off form
last Saturday ov whether it was up
against a superior twelve. For this
reason the Jay rooters are looking
for a large and one-sided score.

R. O. T. C. CEREMONY
TO BE HELD MAY 21
In place of the inspection by
the War Department, an annual event up to this year,
there will be a review and
ceremony for the Hopkins R.
0. T. C. unit on May 21. At
this time there will be a battalion parade, the Board of
Trustees acting as reviewing
officers. Presentation of medals and commissions for next
year's cadet officers and selection of the best drilled company and most proficient private will be made. At present, it seems unlikely that
there will be a sham battle.

Frederick Bauernscmidt, Hamilton Allen and John Eldridge were
publicly initiated into Omicron Delta Kappa• at the spring initiation
held at yesterday's assembly. C.
Gardner Mallonee, who is president
of the honorary society, presided
and presented the initiates with the
0. D. K. laurel.
Leber Speaks

Reverend Charles Leber, who addressed the student body at the assembly, spoke on the great value of
a society such as the honorary organization is. He regarded it as a
stimulus to leadership and as a
means of developing strong character in young men.
The activities of the students
who were initiated into 0. D. K.
represent all the major activities.
Football, basketball, swimming,
Barnstormers, Hullabaloo, and the
musical club, are among those activities in which the trio were engaged.
One Senior

Bauernschmidt was the only
Senior elected, Eldridge and Allen
being members of the Junior class.
The activities through which the
three initiates gained the honor are

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 4, 1928

INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWS

NOTICES

The student paper at Dartmouth
contains some rather vehement and
sarcastic comments on the decency
of that section of the country, as a
result of which two editors of The
Tower, literary magazinie of Dartmouth College, have been forced to
resign. After having three of their
stories rejected because the laws of
the state by which they are governed differ as to what is considered moral and fitting in literature,
the editors finally acknowledged defeat. The aforesaid article which
so strongly condemns the action of
the law comments that the "decency
of New England, which throws
into bold relief the incidental elements of smut, is a parasitic fungus of hypocrisy." All of which
is flowery, high sounding phraseology if nothing else.
* * *
There is also apparently a somewhat similar .state of affairs at
Northwestern University, where
the editorial board of the Purple
Parrot have been requested to resign from office by the faculty. The
cause of this rather curt request by
that dignified body is to be found
in the late American Mercury number of the comic. An advertisement
in this issue dealing with matters of
religious concern is reputed to constitute the chief offense to somewhat old-fashioned conservative
eyes.
*

*

Tuesday, May 8, there will be
a meeting at the A. T. 0. House,
3000 Calvert St., for all those
who aspire to positions in the
Black and Blue Jay Orchestra
for next year. The meeting is
called for 4.00 P. M. All interested should report promptly.
Senior examinations will be
held at the same time as undergraduate examinations and will
not start on May 15, as has
been rumored.

Dean Herbert Hawkes of Columbia University is decidedly an exception among collegiate P. H. D.'s,
if one is to completely accept his
recent statement as it appeared in
the Spectator. Dean Hawkes here
declares himself as being heartily
in favor of snap courses and that
in the subjects he proposes to introduce at Columbia examinations
will be a needless bother. Seriously considering this rather radical stand, we can't exactly discern
what logical reasoning he can offer
as an explanation.

ICYCLES,stereopticon lectures,
and the "gilded" youths with
their horses and carts; at night the
midnight oil burning in student
lamps while the gas lights glared and
flickered across the campus—the
gay nineties when Dad was in
college seem primitive to us to-day.
Now it's sport roadsters, the
movies,and radios. At night
the MAZDA lamp replaces
the midnight oil in dormitory rooms, while modern

street lighting sheds its friendly
glow over the campus.
Without electricity we would
have none of these improvements. To-day's marvel of electrical
invention becomes to-morrow's
accepted utility. In the coming
years, by taking advantage of new
uses of electricity you will be
able to go so much farther
that the "tearing twenties"
will seem just as primitive
as the "gay nineties".

Playing its first out-of-town game
of this season, the Hopkins lacrosse
twelve will meet Swarthmore tomorrow at the latter team's home
field.
It will be interesting to compare
the showing made by Swarthmore
against Hopkins with the result of
the Garnets' contest with the West
Point twelve. Army, which has
been undefeated, upset _ Swarthmore's hopes when it trounced the

prove in some measure whether the
Black and Blue team was off form
last Saturday ov whether it was up
against a superior twelve. For this
reason the Jay rooters are looking
for a large and one-sided score.

R. O. T. C. CEREMONY
TO BE HELD MAY 21
In place of the inspection by
the War Department, an annual event up to this year,
there will be a review and
ceremony for the Hopkins R.
0. T. C. unit on May 21. At
this time there will be a battalion parade, the Board of
Trustees acting as reviewing
officers. Presentation of medals and commissions for next
year's cadet officers and selection of the best drilled company and most proficient private will be made. At present, it seems unlikely that
there will be a sham battle.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 4, 1928

INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWS

NOTICES

The student paper at Dartmouth
contains some rather vehement and
sarcastic comments on the decency
of that section of the country, as a
result of which two editors of The
Tower, literary magazinie of Dartmouth College, have been forced to
resign. After having three of their
stories rejected because the laws of
the state by which they are governed differ as to what is considered moral and fitting in literature,
the editors finally acknowledged defeat. The aforesaid article which
so strongly condemns the action of
the law comments that the "decency
of New England, which throws
into bold relief the incidental elements of smut, is a parasitic fungus of hypocrisy." All of which
is flowery, high sounding phraseology if nothing else.
* * *
There is also apparently a somewhat similar .state of affairs at
Northwestern University, where
the editorial board of the Purple
Parrot have been requested to resign from office by the faculty. The
cause of this rather curt request by
that dignified body is to be found
in the late American Mercury number of the comic. An advertisement
in this issue dealing with matters of
religious concern is reputed to constitute the chief offense to somewhat old-fashioned conservative
eyes.

Tuesday, May 8, there will be
a meeting at the A. T. 0. House,
3000 Calvert St., for all those
who aspire to positions in the
Black and Blue Jay Orchestra
for next year. The meeting is
called for 4.00 P. M. All interested should report promptly.
Senior examinations will be
held at the same time as undergraduate examinations and will
not start on May 15, as has
been rumored.

Professors at Nebraska Wesleyan were recently submitted to an
efficiency and popularity grading.
Following are some of the characteristics which the students found
in the faculty. They are ranked in

Describing collegiate beauty contests as complete inanity and what
not, the dean of women at the University of Denver placed her foot
down strongly on the custom of
selecting annually the most beautiful coed at the institution. The lady
in question is further quoted ars
stating that "these contests are degrading and insulting to girls whose
brains are entirely overlooked and
they place coeds on a level with
Follies girls by setting a false value
on beauty, and making physical
grace the sole standard of achievement!'

INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
(Continued from preceding Column)

Dean Herbert Hawkes of Columbia University is decidedly an exception among collegiate P. H. D.'s,
if one is to completely accept his
recent statement as it appeared in
the Spectator. Dean Hawkes here
declares himself as being heartily
in favor of snap courses and that
in the subjects he proposes to introduce at Columbia examinations
will be a needless bother. Seriously considering this rather radical stand, we can't exactly discern
what logical reasoning he can offer
as an explanation.

When Dad was a"Modern Youth"
ICYCLES,stereopticon lectures,
and the "gilded" youths with
their horses and carts; at night the
midnight oil burning in student
lamps while the gas lights glared and
flickered across the campus—the
gay nineties when Dad was in
college seem primitive to us to-day.
Now it's sport roadsters, the
movies,and radios. At night
the MAZDA lamp replaces
the midnight oil in dormitory rooms, while modern

street lighting sheds its friendly
glow over the campus.
Without electricity we would
have none of these improvements. To-day's marvel of electrical
invention becomes to-morrow's
accepted utility. In the coming
years, by taking advantage of new
uses of electricity you will be
able to go so much farther
that the "tearing twenties"
will seem just as primitive
as the "gay nineties".
